text: - Hello and welcome to Community Chats.
I'm a Aley Hammer
and today we've interviewing Ahu Chhapgar,
the Global CTO over at Zip.
Ahu, welcome to the show.

Can you start by telling
our audience a little bit
about Zip's global operations

and you've recently joined the
company only six months ago
so I wanna know as well what motivated you
to join the amazing team over at Zip?
- Thank you, Aley.
Pleasure to be here and speak to you guys.

You know, Zip's a leader in
global financial services

company and a Buy Now
billionaire provider,

so really they offer fair,
seamless and simple ways

in which people can actually
make payments every single day.

Zip provides flexible,
transparent payment solutions
to individual consumers and SMBs,
so really helping them take control
of their financial future
and helping merchants grow their business
so that's the reason I joined.
It was just an exciting place to be,

and on top of it all,
it's just really enabling
consumers and merchants both.

- Well, it sounds like you
have an awesome team and I know

that you really enjoy the fast
pace of the company and Ahu,
how does AWS actually help you guys
to support your customers?
- Yeah, well, so first of all,
we've been an AWS customer since 2013.
So AWS enabled us to enter the market
at the time at a very low cost
without a whole lot of upfront investment,

being able to provision
capacity flexibly on demand

as we build out new services,
respond to like changes

and transaction volumes and
enable us to move at Zip speed.
So we don't have products.
On the highest standard of infrastructure,

frankly, on AWS, but all the
nonfunctional requirements
baked into the platform.
We've got a better payments business
so like availability, reliability,

scalability is extremely
important to us, right?
Having multiple data centers,

having redundancy
really, really important.

So to the globally integrated
nature of Amazon Web Services

really can provide our
services in different parts

of the world with relatively
seamless connectivity

between regions and we
don't have to put up

a whole lot of time and
investment in doing that,
so getting us up and running, I mean,

that's how we've always
used Amazon Web Services.
- Thanks so much for sharing, Ahu,

and Zip is also leveraging
AWS to remain innovative,

so can you share a little
bit of detail about this?
- Yeah, I'd say a lot of different ways.

We are actually pretty good
at consuming new capabilities
built by AWS on a regular basis.

Well, first off, just
running our development

proud environments in AWS
without on-prem equipment

meant that the switch to remote
working during the pandemic,
as an example, was seamless.

Our engineers have always
been able to connect securely
to our environments, easily from wherever
they happen to be working.
So we use a whole lot of Elastic.

We use cloud native services
like EKS and DynamoDB

that actually allows us
to automatically scale

as our load increases and
as we have like fluctuations

within our load, right, so we
also pre-provision resources
ahead of expected peak periods
so there's lots of ways based

in which we actually use all
the latest AWS capabilities

offered and allows us
to be innovative really.
- Yeah, I mean, as you just mentioned,
you guys are always experimenting
and trying out the new tech
so what kind of new technology are you

currently experimenting
with at the moment?
- Sure.

I'd say we started to
make use of ECS Fargate

Windows containers to host
some of our older workloads

previously running on more
traditional Windows EC2 platforms

within AWS so we've done some
pretty interesting work there.

Our new data platform
is being built on AWS
using best components and services
and we're always looking to like AWS
for the way to level up our capability
and run a first class like analytics game,

so super important, even on
the data and analytics side.

Then I'd say we've started
running some of our workload

on the newer AMD M6
instances to take advantage
of better performance and cost of entail.

If this goes well, the
majority of our workload

will soon run on AMD,
right, so that's a big one.

And then we are exploring,
consolidating the Zip platform
on one shared integrated platform on AWS
as an extremely important,
it's an extremely important area for us.
Like again, be cost efficient and improve

the quality of service that
we offer our customers.
- Well, there's so many projects there.
Thank you so much, Ahu.

And to round up this into,
this is a bit of a tricky one.
I mean, I guess if you had a crystal ball,

what does the future of Fintech,
or I guess Zip look like

and what most excites
you about the industry?

- So, Aley, above all,
I've been with Fintech

for a really long time, right
from my sort of early days

when I was at PayPal and 17
years in I'm still in Fintech.

I would say tons and tons
of exciting opportunities

everywhere, but I, you
know, but above all,
I wanna talk about like just the fact

that Buy Now, Pay Later
is an exciting place.

It's incredible, it's
a humbling opportunity

for us to help people in
need and fill a real gap

which isn't addressed today and
offering these capabilities,
offering these services to people in need,
but also businesses in need

and offering a greater user
experience to our merchants.

So just, you know, that's the
part that really excites me.

Great play on offering
credit to people in need,

that's what I love the most
about Fintech at this point.

- Ahu, thank you so much
for coming on the show.
The partnership between Zip and Amazon
is an incredible partnership.
I use your products, I love your products,

so thank you so much for
coming on the show today.

If anyone has any
questions, please pop them

in the comment section below
and we'll get back to you.
Thanks so much, Ahu.
- Thank you very much, Aley.
